chapter.htmlHeader: What is the prognosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• The prognosis of a sprain or strain largely depends on the severity of the injury [Jarvinen, 2000; BMJ Best Practice, 2018].
    • A mild injury will usually heal within a few weeks with conservative treatment, with minimal risk of long-term complications. 
    • A moderate injury should heal within a few weeks, but there is a high risk of re-injury in the first 4–6 weeks.
    • A severe injury may take months to heal fully, require surgical treatment, and result in complications.
  • CKS found the majority of literature covered the prognosis of ankle sprains.
    • Following an acute lateral ankle sprain, pain decreases rapidly within the first two weeks after injury, but up to 40% of people develop chronic ankle instability [Vuurberg, 2018].
    • In uncomplicated ankle sprain injuries, walking is usually possible within 1–2 weeks, with function restored after 6–8 weeks, and a return to sporting activities after 8–12 weeks (depending on the severity of the injury) [de Bie, 2006].
    • Lateral ankle sprains have the highest recurrence rates of all lower limb musculoskeletal injuries, with a two-fold increased risk of re-injury in the year following initial injury, leading to a large proportion of people developing chronic ankle instability [Gribble, 2016].
    • A systematic review found the long term prognosis of acute ankle sprain is poor, with up to 70% of people reporting persistent residual symptoms and injury recurrence [Doherty, 2017].
    • A systematic review of 31 studies of adults with acute lateral ankle sprains found [van Rijn, 2008]:
      • There was a rapid decrease in pain reporting within the first 2 weeks in the majority of people, after which pain continued to improve more slowly.
      • 5–33% of people still experienced pain after 1 year.
      • 36–85% of people reported full recovery within a period of 3 years.
      • The risk of re-injury affected 3–34% of people, and these occurred 2 weeks to 8 years post-injury.
      • Overall, a wide variation in reported subjective instability, re-injury, and recovery rates was noted among the different studies.
    • A five-year observational follow-up study of acute lateral ankle sprain in primary care (n = 206) found [Mailuhu, 2018]:
      • 18.2% of people had persistent symptoms.
      • 30.3% of people experienced a re-injury during follow up.
      • Persistent symptoms 6–12 months after acute injury, dominant leg injury, and a recurrent injury were significant predictors for persistent symptoms at 5 years follow up.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?
